07

o say that this area is
water-oriented is an understatement.
Indeed, the Chesapeake Bay, Back
River, Old Road Bay, Bear Creek and
countless small tributaries are the
main influence on the history, economy
and way of life of Patapsco Neck and
the Dundalk area. From earliest times,
native Americans lived in this area.









Cuckold Point



Swan Point

Millers Island

Archaeological surveys uncovered
sites of prehistoric villages, no doubt
located here for the abundance of fish
and shellfish, game and wildlife, and
broad, fertile lands for farming.

| European settlers arrived
PLEASURE early on the Patapsco Neck. In fact,

' ISLAND the earliest land patent from the Lord

Proprietor is dated 1658 and named
Planter’s Paradise. Tobacco farming
was profitable on the rich soil with its
easy water transportation to Euro-
pean markets. Products diversified
during the 18th century to include









A\QMAILLMWM/&&MM@&MA

grain and truck farm produce
shipped to Baltimore markets on small
sailing vessels. :

Then, on September 12, 1814,
one of the most dramatic chapters in
U.S. history took place here. Fifty

elcome to the Seventh
Councilmanic District of Baltimore
County. As you drive along the
heavily traveled commercial corridors
of the Dundalk-Essex area, step
back in time by detouring onto the
scenic routes of North Point Road,
Millers Island Road, and the streets of
historic Dundalk.

Drive along North Point and
Millers Island roads through Black
Marsh’s Natural Heritage Area. Pass
the broad fields, woodland, and
waving marsh grasses that are the
hallmark of this area. Or visit historic
Dundalk to enjoy the ambiance of
an early 20th century community
preserved amidst the bustle of
modern life.

The joy of these routes is their

very unexpectedness. Outsiders’

preconceptions of this southeastern

art of Baltimore County are colored
y the omnipresent Bethlehem Steel



-
) Tt
1

P?‘“‘f‘"“-& s

Sl Wi,

e

.

o

o iy .

British ships sailed up the Chesa-
peake intent on seizing Baltimore
as they had Washington, D.C. Six
thousand soldiers, led by General
Ross, landed at the site of the
present Fort Howard Veterans
Hospital and Fort Howard Park and
marched along North Point Road
toward Baltimore, 10 miles away.
Vigilant sentinels along the Bay
warned Baltimore of its danger.
Lookouts at the Todd House on North
Point Road monitored British
progress. After burning the house in
retaliation, the British continued
toward Baltimore. Sharpshooters
skirmished with the British and fatal-
ly wounded General Ross, a severe
blow to the British. At the Battle Acre
Monument site, American forces
engaged the British in what became
known as the Battle of North Point.

For two days the American
forces skirmished with the British.
Hampstead Hill, now Patterson Park,

1s as close as the British forces came

to Baltimore before retreating to their
ships. Their next assault was from
shipboard, firing upon Fort McHenry
as immortalized by Francis Scott Key
in the “Star Spangled Banner.” With
this repulse of the British, the greatest
invasion of the United States by an
enemy force came to an end.

After this brief and exciting
period of history, the Patapsco Neck
area resumed its quiet existence
as farmland until 1887. Then, the
Pennsylvania Steel Company purchas-
ed 1,000 acres to build a steel plant at
Sparrows Point. This decision forever
altered the landscape of the Patapsco
Neck area. Marshes were drained.
Wetlands were filled in with slag. A
planned community grew where

once only muskrats and ducks had-

lived. In the flat, open topography the

plant and myriad other industrial
enterprises. Driving by on the
Beltway reinforces the impression
that this is just a heavy industrial and
commercial area.

But area residents know that
what you see from the Beltway is
only part of the picture. Come tour the
scenic routes to catch a glimpse of
eagles soaring over the marshes,
to fish for catfish, or to dine on
local seafood while watching the sun
set across the Bay. Or find out about
local history. Follow the route that
the British took in 1814 when they
invaded the United States. Imagine
the forgotten delights of Bay Shore
Park. Search for enemy U-boats from
the fortifications of Fort Howard Park
as the World War 1 soldiers did.

All of this is available in the
Seventh Councilmanic District. Follow
these scenic routes, and come find out
for yourself.

towering steel furnaces dominated
everything else. Hundreds and then
thousands of workers were needed to
turn the iron ore shipped up the Bay
from South American mines into
finished steel products.

All of this activity irrevocably
changed the way of life of the people
of the Patapsco Neck area. Streetcar
tracks were laid and roads were built
to make the Sparrows Point plant
more accessible to workers who lived
in Baltimore. The town of Sparrows
Point, now demolished, was built in the
shadows of the plant itself. It provided
all the latest amenities for its workers

Seventh Distric

2 SRS < (‘ b ,
el l’““‘{w-{/d;rl s
/

J ‘ i g 7 & ‘a,:’
/ \ Vi d /N\l‘ v i \\ /.',-.t,////\'skq\, " 'r" i W//
/ PR ) b A A i,



including indoor plumbing, electric
lights, central heating in the houses
and schools, as well as doctors, stores,
and recreation within the community.
All were provided and controlled by
the steel company, which became
known as Bethlehem Steel after 1916.

As production at the plant in-
creased so did the need to house
workers in the vicinity. To meet this
need, Bethlehem Steel purchased 1,000
acres of land surrounding the tiny
village and railway station of Dundalk.
The Dundalk Company was formed to
create a plan for a new town. The
Dundalk plan was based on the

Lot kg

a2 U R i
R it ..o

it ST A

Fort Howard Park



( N =







Swan Point

o . -
= = S o - / r

U( Building



Prepared by the Baltimore County
Office of Planning and Zoning and
the Baltimore County Economic
Development Commission’s Office of
Promotion and Tourism.

W%MMWA\MW%MMM\MAW(LMM -

‘““‘Garden City’’ philosophy of
Frederick Law Olmsted. A “Garden
City” had a central commercial core
flanked by parks, playgrounds,
schools, and churches; all surrounded
by curving, tree-lined streets filled
with gracious European-style homes.
The Roland Park Company translated
this philosophy into the plan that you
see in Dundalk today, billing Dundalk
as the “working man’s Roland Park.”

With the advent of World War 1,
as steel production for ships became
a national priority, the federal
government took over building
Dundalk to house ‘“war workers.”
Approximately 800 houses were built
in the original style and plan of the
Dundalk Company. The town was
fenced and guarded to ensure the safe-
ty of the workers from infiltration by
German spies. .

After the war, the houses grad-
ually were sold to individual
homeowners. In 1983 this area was
listed on the National Register of
Historic Places recognizing its
importance in the history of Baltimore
County. Drive to the commercial
center, park your car, and step back
into the early 20th century. Walk
around the historic district and note
that over the years area residents
have altered little of Dundalk’s plan.
Instead, they have been careful custo-
dians of the dream of Frederick Law
Olmsted and the Dundalk Company.

As the fortunes of the Bethlehem
Steel Company rose and fell, so did the
Patapsco Neck area change and grow.
The late 19th century and early 20th
century was a time of rapid change.
Streetcars and new roads made the
area much more accessible to people
from the city. The beaches of the
Patapsco Neck provided fishing,
boating, hunting, and swimming
opportunities. Private gun clubs
owned waterfront lands and ““ducking
clubs” were very popular. United
Railways built Bay Shore Park, an
amusement park that became a
popular summertime destination, and
initiated the Bay Shore trolley line
to run to the park on weekends. In
spite of all this activity, open fields of
grain and vegetables grown for the

.u}\! _",J s

markets in Baltimore dominated the
land use through the first half of the
20th century.

Residential development was
just around the corner, however. Swan
Point was platted for subdivision in
1924. Hundreds of 50-foot-wide lots
were laid out along what is now
Cuckold Point Road and Hinton
Avenue. Restrictions prohibited com-
mercial buildings (including stores,
businesses, and saloons), keeping cows
or goats, allowing chickens to run free,
or building a home for less than $1,000.
Sales, apparently intended for well-off
families seeking a vacation home on
the water, languished. Many of the lots
were still vacant in 1941, when
acquired from the Polish American
Savings and Loan Association by a
Mr. Welsh. Much of the construction
in this area dates from post World
War II when easy mortgage loans
made homeownership more accessible,
and automobiles made the commute to
work much easier.

Today, much of the area along
Millers Island Road displays its
heritage for all to see. The road winds
through Black Marsh, 1,310 acres of
farmland and wetlands, which now are
owned by the state. This property
once belonged to Bethlehem Steel and
was purchased to ensure that a rival
steel company would be unable to
locate in the area. Now, plans call for
preservation of this area for a wildlife
refuge and a recreational area.

North Point Road and Millers
Island Road are beautiful little areas
tucked away amidst the heavy
industrial and commercial corridors of
southeast Baltimore County. The
streets of Dundalk are remarkably
preserved, attesting to the fact that
a well-planned community is an
enduring place to live in or to visit
75 years after it was built. People
from the Dundalk area appreciate
what their community has to offer.
Other Baltimore County residents are
urged to follow the map and explore
for themselves.

Baltimore County Scenic Roads



Spectacular views of the bay,
boating, crabbing and fishing,
wildlife habitats, and important
historic sites—these are just a few of

Seventh Councilmanic District. |
urge everyone to visit this unique
area of Baltimore County to enjoy a

TS 7

Dennis F. Rasmussen
County Executive

As a lifelong resident of the
Dundalk-Edgemere area, I am
delighted to offer the opportunity to
all Baltimore County residents to
explore the Seventh Councilmanic
District. | hope you enjoy your visit
as much as we residents enjoy
living here.

N7

Dale T. Volz
Councilman,
Seventh District



County Executive

Dennis E Rasmussen
and the
Baltimore County Council



the attractions of Baltimore County’s

day of sightseeing or water-related fun.

5



Seventh District
